subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Denmark , Estonia , Finland , Latvia , Lithuania , Norway , Sweden , Russian Fennoscandia.—Transpalearctic/Holarctic: from West Europe and North Africa to China , Korea and Japan . Introduced accidentally to North America ( Bohart & Kimsey 1982 ).

Remarks. The species is common in all Nordic and Baltic countries, and the northernmost records are from Lapland (north of 68° latitude). Hellén (1920 , 1935 ) reported the form “ab. viridiventris ” from Finland , which differs from the normal form by possessing a green abdomen. Variation in abdominal colouration is common in this species, and different colourations can also result from different collection and preservation methods. The closely related species
Pseudomalus triangulifer
was not distinguished from
P. auratus
prior to the late 1950s in the Nordic and Baltic countries. Thus earlier published records of
P. auratus
could represent either species.
